Yield now, or you are undone: your good name's perished
Not all the world can buy your reputation;
'Tis sunk for ever else, these people's tongues will poison ye
Though you be white as innocence, they'll taint ye,
They will speak terrible and hideous things,
And people in this age are prone to credit,
They'll let fell nothing that may brand a woman,
Consider this, and then be wise and tremble:
Yield yet, and yet I'll save ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I'll show ye,
Their mouths I'll seal up, they shall speak no more
But what is honourable and honest of ye,
And saintlike they shall worship ye: they are mine,
And what I charge 'em Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I am ruined,
Heaven will regard me yet, they are barbarous wretches:
Let me not fall (My lord.)

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You shall not Florimell:
Mark how I'll work your peace, and how I honour ye.
Who waits there? come all in.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Who dare say this sweet beauty is not heavenly?
This virgin, the most pure, the most untainted,
The holiest thing?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We know it (My dear lord)
We are her slaves: and that proud impudence
That dares disparage her, this sword (My lord.)

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: They are rascals, base, the sons of common women
That wrong this virtue, or dare own a thought
But fair and honourable of her: when we slight her,
Hang us, or cut's in pieces: let's tug i'th' galleys.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Brand us for villains.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why sure I dream: these are all saints.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Go, and live all her slaves.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We are proud to do it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: What think ye now? am not I able Florimell
Yet to preserve ye?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I am bound to your lordship,
Ye are all honour, and good my lord but grant me
Until tomorrow leave to weigh my fortunes,
I'll give you a free answer, perhaps a pleasing,
Indeed I'll do the best I can to satisfy ye.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.p: Take your good time, this kiss, till then farewell, sweet. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By all means discharge your follower.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If we can get him off: sirrah Bustofa.
Thou must needs run back.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: But I must not unless you send
A bier, or a lictor at my back, I do not use to run
From my friends.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, go will serve turn: I have forgotten.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: What sir,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: See if I can think on't now.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I know what 'tis now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A pistolet of that.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Done, you have forgotten a device to send me away,
You are going a smocking perhaps.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: His own, due, due i'faith Antonio,
The Pistolet's his own.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I confess it,
There 'tis: now if you could afford out of it
A reasonable excuse to mine uncle.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Yes, I can:
But an excuse will not serve your turn: it must be a lie,
A full lie, 'twill do no good else: if you'll go to
The price of that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is a lie dearer than an excuse?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: O, treble; this is the price of an excuse: but a lie is two more:
Look how many foils go to a fair fall, so many excuses to
A full lie, and less cannot serve your turn, let any tailor
I'th' town make it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wie, 'tis reasonable, give him his price:
Let it be large enough now.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I'll warrant you, cover him all over.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would have proof of one now.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: What? scale my invention before hand? you shall pardon
Me for that: well, I'll commend you to your uncle, and
Tell him you'll be at home at supper with him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By no means, I cannot come tonight (Man)

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I know that too, you do not know a lie when you see it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Remember it must stretch for all night.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: I shall want stuff, I doubt 'twill come to the other pistolet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, lay out, you shall be no loser sir.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: It must be faced, you know, there will be a yard of dissimulation
At least (City-measure) and cut upon an untruth or two: lined
With fables, that must needs be, cold weather's coming, if it had
A galloon of hypocrisy, 't would do well: and hooked
Together with a couple of conceits,
That's necessity; well, I'll bring in my
Bill: I'll warrant you as fair a lie by that time I have done
With it, as any gentleman i'th' town can swear too: if he
Would betray his lord and master. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So, so, this necessary trouble's over.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I would you had bought an excuse of him
Before he went: you'll want one for Ismenia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tush, there needs none, there's no suspicion yet,
And I'll be armed before the next encounter,
In a fast tie with my fair Isabel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, you'll find your errand is before you now.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: O gentlemen, look to yourselves, ye are
Men of another world else: your enemies are upon you;
The old house of the Bellides will fall upon your heads:
Signior Lisauro.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lisauro?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: And don what call you him? he's a gentleman:
Yet he has but a yeoman's name,
Don Tarso, Tarso, and a dozen at their heels.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lisauro, Tarso, nor a dozen more
Shall fright me from my ground, nor shun my path,
Let 'em come on in their ablest fury.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis worthily resolved: I'll stand by you sir,
This way, I am thy true friend.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I'll be gone sir, that one may live to tell what's become of you.
Put up, put up, will you never learn to know a lie
From an Esop's fables? there's a taste for you now. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Look sir, what time of day is it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I know not, my eyes go false, I dare not trust 'em now,
I prithee tell me (Martin) if thou canst,
Is that Ismenia, or Isabella.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is the lady, forget not Isabella.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If this face may be borrowed and lent out,
If it can shift shoulders, and take other tires,
So, 'tis mine where ere I find it

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Be sudden:Exit Aminta.
I cannot hold out long.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Believe't she frowns.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it come, she cannot frown me off on't:
How prettily it woos me to come nearer?
How do you (Lady) since yesterday's pains?
Were you not weary? of my faith.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I think you were.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What lady?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Weary of your faith, 'tis a burden
That men faint under, though they bear little of it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So, this is to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You came home
In a fair hour I hope? Enter Aminta.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: From whence sir?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Sir, there's a gentlewoman without desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They were pretty homely toys: but your presence
Made them illustrious.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: My cousin speaks to you.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A gentlewoman sir, Isabella
She names herself.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So, so, it hits finely now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Name yourself how you please: speak what you please,
I'll hear you cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: You are not well,
Request her in: she may have more acquaintance
With his passions, and better cure for 'em.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: She's nice in that (Madam) poor soul it seems
She's fearful of your displeasure.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I'll quit her
From that presently, and bring her in myself. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How carelessly do you behave yourself?
When you should call all your best faculties
To council in you: how will you answer
The breach you made with fair Ismenia?
Have you forgotten the retrograde vow you took
With her, that now is come in evidence?
You'll die upon your shame, you need no more
Enemies of the house, but the lady now:
You shall have your dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give me that face,
And I am satisfied upon whose shoulders
Soe'er it grows: Juno deliver us
Out of this amazement: beseech you goddess
Tell us of our friends, how dos Ismenia?
And how does Isabella? both in good health
I hope, as you yourself are.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I am at farthest
In my counterfeit: my Antonio
I have matter against you may need pardon,
As I must crave of you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Observe you sir,
What evidence is come against me? what think you
The hydra-headed jury will say to't?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis I am fooled,
My hopes are poured into the bottomless tube,
'Tis labour for the house of Bellides:
I must not seem so yet: but in sooth (Lady)
Did you imagine your changeable face
Hid you from me? by this hand I knew you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I went by the face: and by these eyes I
Might have been deceived.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: You might indeed (Antonio)
For this gentleman did vow to Isabella,
That he it was that loved Ismenia,
And not Antonio?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good, and was not that
A manifest confession that I knew you?
I else had been unjust unto my friend:
'Twas well remembered, there I found you out
And speak your conscience now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But did he so protest?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Yes, I vow to you, had Antonio
Wedded Isabella, Ismenia
Had not been lost, there had been her lover.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why much good do you friend, take her to you:
I crave but one, here have I my wish full,
I am glad we shall be so near neighbours.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take both sir, Juno to boot: three parts in one,
S. Hilary bless you, now opportunity
Beware to meet with falsehood, if thou canst
Shun it, my friend's faith's turning from him.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Might I not justly accuse Antonio
For a love-wanderer? you know no other
But me, for another, and confess troth now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here was my guide, where ere I find this face,
I am a lover, marry, I must not miss
This freckle then, I have the number of 'em,
Nor this dimple: not a silk from this brow,
I carry the full idea ever with me;
If nature can so punctually parallel,
I may be cozened.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Well, all this is even:
But now, to perfect all, our love must now
Come to our enemies hands, where neither part
Will ever give consent to't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Most certain:
For which reason it must not be put to 'em:
Have we not prevention in our own hands.
Shall I walk by the tree? desire the fruit,
Yet be so nice to pull till I ask leave
Of the churlish gardener, that will deny me?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: O Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis manners to fall to
When grace is said.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: That holy act is to come.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You may open an oyster or two before grace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are there not double vows, as valuable
And as well spoken as any friar utters?
Heaven has heard all.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Yes: but stays the blessing,
Till all dues be done: heaven is not served by halfs.
We shall have ne'er a father's blessing here,
Let us not lose the better, from above.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You take up weapons of unequal force,
It shows you cowardly: hark in your ear.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Have I lost all employment? Would this proffer
Had been made to me, though I had paid it
With a reasonable penance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have I passed
All thy forelock (Time)? I'll stretch a long arm
But I'll catch hold again: do but look back
Over thy shoulder, and have a pull at thee.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I hear you (Sir) nor can I hear too much
While you speak well: you know th' accustomed place
Of our night parley: if you can ascend,
The window shall receive you. You may find there
A corrupted churchman to bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would meet no other man.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Aminta, you hear this.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: With joy (Madam) 'cause it pleases you.
It may be mine own case another time:
Now you go the right way: ask the banes out,
Put it passed father, or friends, to forbid it,
And then you're sure. Sir, your Hymen taper
I'll light up for you: the window shall show you
The way to Sestos.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll venture drowning.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The simile holds not; 'tis hanging rather.
You must ascend your castle by a ladder;
To the foot I'll bring you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Leave me to climb it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If I do turn you off?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Till night farewell:
Then better.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Best it should be;
But peevish hatred keeps back that degree. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I never looked so smooth as now I purpose:
And then beware: knave is at worst of knave
When he smiles best, and the most seems to save. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My mind's unquiet; while Antonio
My nephew's abroad, my heart is not at home,
Only my fears stay with me; bad company;
But I cannot shift 'em off. This hatred
Betwixt the house of Bellides and us,
Is not fair war: 'tis civil, but uncivil.
We are near neighbours, were of love as near,
Till a cross misconstruction ('twas no more
In conscience) put us so far asunder:
I would 'twere reconciled; it has lasted
Too many sunsets, if grace might moderate:
Man should not lose so many days of peace
To satisfy the anger of one minute.
I could repent it heartily. I sent
The knave to attend my Antonio too,Enter Bustofa.
Yet he returns no comfort to me neither.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: No: I must not.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ha; he's come.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I must not: 'twill break his heart to hear it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How? there's bad tidings: I must obscure and hear it;
He will not tell me for breaking of my heart,
'Tis half split already.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: I have spied him: now to knock down a don with a lie, a silly harmless lie; 'twill be valiantly done, and nobly perhaps.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I cannot hear him now.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: O the bloody days that we live in; the envious, malicious, deadly days that we draw breath in!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now I hear too loud.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: The children that never shall be born may rue it; for men that are slain now might have lived to have got children, that might have cursed their fathers.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O, my posterity is ruined.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: O sweet Antonio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O dear Antonio.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Yet it was nobly done of both parts: when he and Lisauro met,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O, death has parted 'em.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Welcome my mortal foe (Says one), welcome my deadly enemy (Says th'other:) off go their doublets, they in their shirts, and their swords stark naked; here lies Antonio, here lies Lisauro: he comes upon him with an embroccado, that he puts by with a puncta reversa; Lisauro recoils me two paces and some six inches back, takes his career, and then, o.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Runs Antonio quite thorough,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O villain.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Quite thorough between the arm and the body: so yet he had no hurt at that bout.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Goodness be praised.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: But then, at next encounter, he fetches me up Lisauro; Lisauro makes out a long at him, which he thinking to be a passado, Antonio's foot slipping: down: o down.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O now thou art lost.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: O, but the quality of the thing: both gentlemen, both Spanish Christians, yet one man to shed

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Say his enemy's blood.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: His hair may come by divers casualties, though he never go into the field with his foe: but a man to lose nine ounces and two drams of blood at one wound, thirteen and a scruple at another, and to live till he die in cold blood: yet the surgeon (That cured him) said, if pia-mater had not been perished, he had been a life's man till this day.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: There he concludes he is gone.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: But all this is nothing: now I come to the point.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I the point, that's deadly: the ancient blow
Over the buckler ne'er went half so deep.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p:
Yet pity bids me keep in my charity: for me to pull an old man's ears from his head with telling of a tale: o foul tale! No, be silent tale. Furthermore, there is the charge of burial; every one will cry blacks, blacks, that had but the least finger dipped in his blood, though ten degrees removed when 'twas done. Moreover,
the surgeon (That made an end of him) will be paid: sugar-plums and sweet breads; yet I say, the man may recover again, and die in his bed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What motley stuff is this? Sirrah, speak truth
What hath befallen my dear Antonio?
Restrain your pity in concealing it;
Tell me the danger full; take off your care
Of my receiving it: kill me that way,
I'll forgive my death: what thou keepest back from truth
Thou shalt speak in pain; do not look to find
A limb in his right place, a bone unbroke,
Nor so much flesh unbroiled of all that mountain
As a worm might sup on; dispatch, or be dispatched.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Alas sir, I know nothing, but that Anton. is a man of god's making to this hour, 'tis not two since I left him so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Where didst thou leave him?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: In the same clothes he had on when he went from you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Does he live?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I saw him drink.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Is he not wounded?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: He may have a cut i'th' leg by this time; for don Martin and he were at whole slashes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Met he not with Lisauro?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I do not know her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Her? Lisauro is a man, as he is.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I saw ne'er a man like him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Didst thou not discourse a fight betwixt Ant. and lis. ?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: I to myself; I hope a man may give himself the lie if it please him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Didst thou lie then?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: As sure as you live now.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I live the happier by it: when will he return?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: That he sent me to tell you, within these ten days at farthest.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ten days? he's not wont to be absent two.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Nor I think he will not: he said he would be at home tomorrow; but I love to speak within my compass.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You shall speak within mine sir, now. Within there:
Take this fellow into custody, keep him safe
I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Safe? do you hear? take notice what plight you find me in, if there want but a collop or a steak o'me, look to't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If my nephew return not in his health tomorrow,
Thou goest to th' rack.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Let me go to th' manger first; I had rather eat oats then hay. Exeunt.Enter Bellides with a letter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: By your leave, sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: For ought I know yet, you are welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Read that, and tell me so: or if thy spectacles be not easy,
Keep thy nose unsaddled, and open thine ears;
I can speak thee the contents, I made 'em;
'Tis a challenge, a fair one, I'll maintain 't:
I scorn to hire my second to deliver 't,
I bring 't myself: dost know me, Julio?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Bellides?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes: is not thine hair on end now?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Somewhat amazed at thy rash hardiness;
How durst thou come so near thine enemy?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Dared?
I dare come nearer: thou'rt a fool, Julio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Take it home to thee with a knave to boot.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Knave to thy teeth again: and all that's quit:
Give me not a fool more than I give thee,
Or if thou dost, look to hear on't again.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What an encounter's this?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A noble one:
My hand is to my words, thou hast it there,
There I do challenge thee, if thou dar'st be,
Good friends with me; or I'll proclaim thee coward.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be friends with thee?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll show thee reasons for't:
A pair of old coxcombs (Now we go together)
Such as should stand examples of discretion,
The rules of grammar to unwilling youth
To take out lessons by; we that should check
And quench the raging fire in others bloods,
We strike the battle to destruction?
Read 'em the black art? and make 'em believe
It is divinity? Heathens, are we not?
Speak thy conscience, how hast thou slept this month,
Since this fiend haunted us?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sure, some good angel
Was with us both last night: speak thou truth now,
Was it not last night's motion?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Dost not think
I would not lay hold of it at first proffer?
Should I ne'er sleep again?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Take not all from me;
I'll tell the doctrine of my vision.
Say that Antonio (Best of thy blood)
Or any one, the least allied to thee,
Should be the prey unto Lisauro's sword,
Or any of the house of Bellides?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mine was the just inversion: on, on.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How would thine eyes have emptied thee in sorrow,
And left the condiment of nature dry?
Thy hands have turned rebellious to the balls,
And broke the glasses, with thine own curses
Have torn thy soul, left thee a statue
To propagate thy next posterity.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, and thou causer? so it said to me,
They fight but your mischiefs: the young men were friends,
As is the life and blood coagulate
And curded in one body; but this is yours,
An inheritance that you have gathered for 'em,
A legacy of blood, to kill each other
Throughout your generations. Was't not so?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Word for word.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nay, I can go farther yet.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis far enough; let us atone it here.
And in a reconciled circle fold
Our friendship new again.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The sign's in gemini,
An auspicious house, 't has joined both ours again.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You cannot proclaim me coward now, don Bellides

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No: thou'rt a valiant fellow: so am I:
I'll fight with thee at this hug, to the last leg
I have to stand on, or breath or life left.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This is the salt unto humanity,
And keeps it sweet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Love! o life stinks without it.
I can tell you news.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Good has long been wanting.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I do suspect, and I have some proof on't,
(So far as a love epistle comes to)
That Antonio (Your nephew) and my daughter
Ismenia are very good friends before us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That were a double wall about our houses,
Which I could wish were builded.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I had it
From Antonio's intimate, don Martin:
And yet ( methought ) it was no friendly part
To show it me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Perhaps 't was his consent:
Lovers have policies as well as statesmen:
They look not always at the mark they aim at.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We'll take up cudgels, and have one bout with 'em,
They shall know nothing of this union:
And till they find themselves most desperate,
Succour shall never see 'em.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll take your part sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It grows late; there's a happy day passed us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The example I hope to all behind it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Stand fair, light of love, which epithet and place
Adds to thee honour, to me it would be shame,
We must be weight in love, no grain too light;
Thou art the landmark, but if love be blind,
(As many that can see have so reported)
What benefit canst thou be to his darkness?
Love is a jewel (Some say) inestimable,
But hung at the ear, deprives our own sight,
And so it shines to others, not ourselves.
I speak my skill, I have only heard on't,
But I could wish a nearer document,
Alas, the ignorant desire to know:
Some say love's but a toy, and with a but.
Now methinks I should love it ne'er the worse,
A toy is harmless sure, and may be played with,
It seldom goes without his adjunct, pretty,
A pretty toy we say, 'tis meeter to joy too.
Well, here may be a mad night yet for all this,
Here's a priest ready, and a lady ready:
A chamber ready, and a bed ready,
'Tis then but making unready, and that's soon done:
My lady is my cousin; ay, myself,
Which is nearest then? My desires are mine,
Say they be hers too, is't a hanging matter?
It may be ventured in a worser cause,
I must go question with my conscience:
I have the word; centinel, do thou stand,
Thou shalt not need to call, I'll he at hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are we not dogged behind us, thinkst thou friend?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I heard not one bark, sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There are that bite
And bark not (Man) methought I spied two fellows
That through two streets together walked aloof,
And wore their eyes suspiciously upon us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your jealousy, nothing else; or such perhaps
As are afraid as much of us, who knows
But about the like business? but for your fears sake
I'll advise and entreat one courtesy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's that friend?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will not be denied, sir,
Change your upper garments with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It needs not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I think so too, but I will have it so,
If you dare trust me with the better sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If there should be danger towards,
There will be the main mark I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here thou takest from me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tush, the general
Must be safe, howe'er the battle goes:
See you the beacon yonder?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, we are near shore.

div.stage: Enter 2. Gentlemen with weapons drawn, they set upon Martin: Antonio pursues them out in rescue of Martin.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, land, land, you must clamber by the cliff,
Here are no stairs to rise by.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ay, are you there?Fight and exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Aminta above, and Martin returned again, ascends.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Antonio?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes Ismenia.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Thine own.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Quench the light, thine eyes are guides illustrious.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: 'Tis necessary. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your legs have saved your lives, who ere you are,
Friend. Martin? where art thou? not hurt I hope:
Sure I was farthest in the pursuit of 'em:
My pleasures are forgotten through my fears:
The lights extinct, it was discreetly done:
They could not but have notice of the broil,
And fearing that might call up company,
Have carefully prevented, and closed up:
I do commend the heed; o, but my friend,
I fear his hurt: friend? friend? it cannot be
So mortal, that I should lose thee quite, friend?
A groan, any thing that may discover thee:
Thou art not sunk so far, but I might hear thee:
I'll lay mine ear as low as thou canst fall:
Friend, don Martin, I must answer for thee,
'Twas in my cause thou fellest, if thou beest down,
Such dangers stand betwixt us and our joys,
That should we forethink ere we undertake,
We'd sit at home, and save. What a night's here?
Purposed for so much joy, and now disposed
To so much wretchedness? I shall not rest in't:
If I had all my pleasures there within,
I should not entertain 'em with a smile.
Good night to you: mine will be black and sad,
A friend cannot, a woman may be bad. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: O thou false,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Do your daringest, he's mine own,
Soul and body mine, church and chamber mine,
Totally mine.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Dar'st thou face thy falsehood?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Shall I not give a welcome to my wishes
Come home so sweetly: farewell your company
Till you be calmer woman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: O what a heap
Of misery has one night brought with it. Ent. Ant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is he? do you turn your shame from me?
You're a blind adultress, you know you are.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: How's that Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Till I have vengeance,
Your sin's not pardonable: I'll have him,
If hell hide him not: you've had your last of him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: What did he speak? I understood him not,
He called me a foul name, it was not mine,
He took me for another sure.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ha? are you there?
Where's your sweet heart? I have found you traitor
To my house: wilt league with mine enemy?
You'll shed his blood, you'll say: hah? will you so?
And fight with your heels upwards? No minion,
I have a husband for you, since you're so rank,
And such a husband as thou shalt like him,
Whether thou wilt or no: Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: It thunders with the storm now.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And tonight
I'll have it dispatched: I'll make it sure, ay,
By tomorrow this time thy maidenhead
Shall not be worth a chicken, if it were
Knocked at an outcry: go, I'll ha' ye before me:
Shough, shough, up to your coop, pea hen.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Then I'll try my wings. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay, are you good at that? stop, stop thief, stop there. Exit.

div.head: Scaena secunda.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now having leisure, and a happy wind,
Thou mayst at pleasure cause the stones to grind,
Sails spread, and grist here ready to be ground.
Fie, stand not idly, but let the mill go round.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Why dost thou sing and dance thus? why so merry?
Why dost thou look so wantonly upon me?
And kiss my hands?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If I were high enough,
I would kiss your lips too.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Do, this is some kindness,
This tastes of willingness, nay, you may kiss
Still, but why o'th' sudden now does the fit take ye,
Unoffered, or uncompelled? why these sweet courtesies?
Even now you would have blushed to death to kiss thus:
Prithee let me be prepared to meet thy kindness,
I shall be unfurnished else to hold thee play, wench:
Stay now a little, and delay your blessings:
If this be love, methinks it is too violent:
If you repent you of your strictness to me,
It is so sudden, it wants circumstance.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Fie, how dull?

body.head: 2. Song.
body.l: How long shall I pine for love?
How long shall I sue in vain?
How long like the turtle-dove
Shall I heavily thus complain?
Shall the sails of my love stand still?
Shall the grists of my hopes be unground?
O fie, o fie, o fie,
Let the mill, let the mill go round.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Prithee be calm a little,
Thou mak'st me wonder, thou that wert so strange,
And read such pious rules to my behaviour
But yesternight: thou that wert made of modesty,
Shouldst in a few short minutes turn thus desperate.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You are too cold.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I do confess I freeze now,
I am another thing all over me:
It is my part to woo, not to be courted:
Unfold this riddle, 'tis to me a wonder,
That now o'th' instant ere I can expect,
Ere I can turn my thoughts, and think upon
A separation of your honest carriage
From the desires of youth, thus wantonly,
Thus beyond expectation.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will tell ye,
And tell ye seriously, why I appear thus,
To hold ye no more ignorant and blinded,
I have no modesty, I am truly wanton:
I am that you look for sir; now come up roundly:
If my strict face and counterfeited staledness
Could have won on ye, I had caught ye that way,
And you should ne'er have come to have known who hurt ye.
Prithee (Sweet count) be more familiar with me.
However we are open in our natures,
And apt to more desires than you dare meet with,
Yet we affect to lay the gloss of good on 't:
I saw you touched not at the bait of chastity,
And that it grew distasteful to pour palate
To appear so holy, therefore I take my true shape:
Is your bed ready sir? you shall quickly find me.

body.head: 3. Song.
body.l: On the bed I'll throw thee, throw thee down;
Down being laid, shall we be afraid
To try the rights that belong to love?
No, no, there I'll woo thee with a crown,
Crown our desires, kindle the fires,
When love requires we should wanton prove:
We'll kiss, we'll sport, we'll laugh, we'll play,
If thou comest short, for thee I'll stay,
If thou unskilful art the ground,
I'll kindly teach, we'll have the mill go round.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Are ye no maid?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alas (My lord) no certain:
I am sorry you are so innocent to think so,
Is this an age for silly maids to thrive in?
It is so long too since I lost it sir,
That I have no belief I ever was one:
What should you do with maidenheads? you hate 'em,
They are peevish pettish things, that hold no game up,
No pleasure neither, they are sport for surgeons:
I'll warrant you I'll fit you beyond maidenhead:
A fair and easy way men travel right in,
And with delight, discourse, and twenty pleasures,
They enjoy their journey; mad men creep through hedges.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I am metamorphosed: why do you appear,
I conjure ye, beyond belief thus wanton?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Because I would give ye
Pleasure beyond belief.

body.head: 4. Song.
body.l: Think me still in my father's mill,
Where I have oft been found-a
Thrown on my back, on a well-filled sack,
While the mill has still gone round-a:
Prithee sirrah try thy skill,
And again let the mill go round-a.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Then you have traded?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Traded? how should I know else how to live sir,
And how to satisfy such lords as you are,
Our best guests, and our richest?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: How I shake now?
You take no base men?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Any that will offer,
All manner of men, and all religion's sir,
We touch at in our time: all states and ages,
We exempt none.

body.head: 5. Song.
body.l: The young one, the old one, the fearful, the bold one,
The lame one, though ne'er so unsound,
The Jew or the Turk, have leave for to work,
The whilst that the mill goes round,

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You are a common thing then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No matter since you have your private pleasure,
And have it by an artist excellent,
Whether I am thus, or thus, your men can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: My men? Defend me, how I freeze together,
And am on ice? do I bite at such an orange
After my men? I am preferred.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why stay ye?
Why do we talk my lord, and lose our time?
Pleasure was made for lips, and sweet embraces,
Let lawyers use their tongues: pardon me modesty,
This desperate way must help, or I am miserable.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: She turns, and wipes her face, she weeps for certain,
Some new way now, she cannot be thus beastly,
She is too excellent fair to be thus impudent:
She knows the elements of common looseness,
The art of lewdness: that, that, that, how now, sir.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: The King (An't please your lordship) is alighted close at the gate.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: The King?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: And calls for ye sir.
Means to breakfast here too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Then I am happy.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Stolen so suddenly? go lock her up,
Lock her up where the courtiers may not see her,
Lock her up closely, sirrah, in my closet.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I will (My lord) what does she yield yet? Exit.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Peace:
She is either a damned devil, or an angel,
No noise (Upon your life dame) but all silence.

div.stage: Enter King, lords, Vertigo, Lisauro, Terso.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Your majesty heaps too much honour on me,
With such delight to view each several corner
Of a rude pile: there's no proportion in't, sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Methinks 'tis handsome, and the rooms along
Are neat, and well contrived: the gallery
Stands pleasantly and sweet: what rooms are these?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: They are sluttish ones.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, I must see.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Pray ye do sir,
They are lodging-chambers over a homely garden.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fit still, and handsome; very well: and those?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.p: Those lead to the other side o'th' house, an't like ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let me see those.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Ye may, the doors are open.
What should this view mean? I am half suspicious.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This little room?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: 'Tis mean: a place for trash sir,
For rubbish of the house.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I would see this too:
I will see all.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I beseech your majesty,
The savour of it, and the course appearance.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis not so bad, you would not offend your house with it,
Come, let me see.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Faith sir,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'faith I will see.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: My groom has the key sir, and 'tis ten to one

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But I will see it: force the lock (My lords)
There be smiths enough to mend it: I perceive
You keep some rare things here, you would not show sir.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Here's a fair maid indeed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By my faith is she
A handsome girl: come forward, do not fear wench.
I marry, here's a treasure worth concealing:
Call in the miller.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Then I am discovered.
I confess all before the miller comes sir,
'Twas but intention, from all act I am clear yet.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is this your daughter?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, and 't please your highness.
This is the shape of her, for her substance sir,
Whether she be now honourable or dishonourable:
Whether she be a white-rose, or a canker, is the question:
I thank my lord, he made bold with my Philly,
If she be for your pace, you had best preserve her sir,
She is tender mouthed, let her be broken handsomely.
Maid, were you stolen?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I went not willingly,
And 't please your grace, I was never bred so boldly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How has he used ye?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yet sir, very nobly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Be sure ye tell truth, and be sure (My lord)
You have not wronged her: if ye have, I tell ye
You have lost me, and yourself too: speak again (Wench)

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He has not wronged me, sir; I am yet a maid:
By all that's white and innocent, I am sir,
Only I suffered under strong temptations
The heat of youth; but heaven delivered me.
My lord, I am no whore, for all I feigned it,
And feigned it cunningly, and made ye loathe me:
'Twas time to outdo you: I had been robbed else,
I had been miserable, but I forgive ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What recompense for this?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: A great one sir,
First a repentance, and a hearty one.
Forgive me sweet.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I do my lord.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I thank ye;
The next take this, and these: all I have Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No good my lord, these often corrupt maidens:
I dare not touch at these; they are lime for virgins;
But if you'll give me.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Any thing in my power.
Or in my purchase.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Take heed (Noble sir)
You'll make me a bold asker.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Ask me freely.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ask you? I do ask you, and I deserve ye,
I have kept ye from a crying sin would damn ye
To men and time: I have preserved your credit,
That would have died to all posterity:
Curses of maids shall never now afflict ye,
Nor parents bitter tears make your name barren:
If he deserves well that redeems his country,
And as a patriot be remembered nobly,
Nay, set the highest: may not I be worthy
To be your friend, that have preserved your honour?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You are, and thus I take ye: thus I seal ye
Mine own, and only mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Count, she deserves ye,
And let it be my happiness to give ye,
I have given a virtuous maid, now I dare say it,
'Tis more than blood; I'll pay her portion sir,
An't shall be worthy you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I'll sell my mill,
I'll pay some too: I'll pay the fiddlers,
And we'll have all i' th' country at this wedding,
Pray let me give her too, here my lord take her,
Take her with all my heart, and kiss her freely,
Would I could give you all this hand has stolen too,
In portion with her, 'twould make her a little whiter.
The wind blows fair now, get me a young miller.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: She must have new clothes.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yes marry must she.
If't please ye (Madam) let me see the state of you body.
I'll fit you instantly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Art not thou gone yet?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And 't please your grace, a gown, a handsome gown now,
An orient gown.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, take thy pleasure of her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Of cloth of tissue I can fit ye (Madam)
My lords, stand out o'th' light, a curious body,
The neatest body in Spain this day: with embroidered flowers,
A clinquant petticoat of some rich stuff,
To catch the eye: I have a thousand fashions.
O sleeve, oh sleeve: I'll study all night (Madam)
To magnify your sleeve.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Do, superstitious tailor,
When ye have more time.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Make me no more than woman,
And I am thine.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Sir, haply my wardrobe with your help
May fit her instantly: will you try her?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If I fit her not, your wardrobe cannot.
But if the fashion be not there, you mar her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is my offence so great, ere I be convict,
To be torn with rascals? If it be law,
Let 'em be wild horses, rather than these.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: This is a man suspected of murder, if it please your grace.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It pleases me not (Friend). But who suspects him?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: We that are your highness' extraordinary officers,
We that have taken our oaths to maintain you in peace.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Twill be a great charge to you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis a great charge indeed; but then we call our neighbours to help us. This gentleman and another were fallen out (Yet that's more than I am able to say, for I heard no words between 'em, but what their weapons spoke, Clash, and clatter) which we seeing, came with our bills of government, and first knocked down their weapons, and then the men.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And this you did to keep the peace?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, and 't like your grace, we knocked 'em down to keep the peace: this we laid hold on, the other we set in the stocks. That I could do by mine own power, without your majesty. Enter Aminta.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How so, sir?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I am a shoemaker by my trade.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: O my husband!
Why stands my husband as a man endangered?
Restore him me, as you are merciful,
I'll answer for him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What woman's this? what husband? hold thy bawling,
I know thee for no wife.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You married me last night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou liest: I neither was in church nor house
Last night, nor saw I thee: a thing that was my friend,
I scorn to name now, was with Ismenia,
Like a thief, and there he violated
A sacred trust. This thou mayst know (Aminta).

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Are not you he?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No; nor a friend of his:
Would I had killed him: I hope I have.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: That was my husband (Royal sir) that man,
That excellent man. Enter Bellides.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That villain, that thief.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Have I caught you sir? well overtaken.
This is mine enemy: pardon (My sovereign).

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Good charity, to crave pardon for your enemy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mine own pardon (Sir) for my joys rudeness:
In what place better could I meet my foe,
And both of us so well provided too?
He with some black bloodthirsty crime upon him,
That (Ere the horseleech burst) will suck him dry:
I with a second accusation,
Enough to break his neck, if need should be,
And then to have even justice self to right us:
How should I make my joys a little civil,
They might not keep this noise?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here is some hope.
Should the axe be dull, the halter's preparing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What's your accusation, sir? We have heard the former. Enter Julio.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mine (My lord)? A strong one.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A false one, sir.
At least malicious: an evidence
Of hatred and despite: he would accuse
My poor kinsman of that he never dreamed of,
Nor waking saw; the stealing of his daughter,
She whom, I know, he would not look upon.
Speak Antonio, didst thou ever see her?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes sir, I have seen her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ah ha, friend Julio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He might, but how? with an unheedful eye,
An accidental view, as men see multitudes
That the next day dare not precisely say
They saw that face, or that amongst 'em all,
Didst thou so look on her?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Guilty, guilty:
His looks hang themselves.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your patience (Gentleman).
I pray you tell me if I be in error,
I may speak often when I should but hear:
This is some show you would present us with,
And I do interrupt it: pray you speak,
(It seems no more) is 't any thing but a show?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My lord, this gentlewoman can show you all,
So could my daughter too, if she were here;
By this time they are both immodest enough:
She's fled me, and I accuse this thief for't.
Don Martin, his own friend is my testimony:
A practised nightwork.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That martin's the other
In your custody; he was forgotten:
Fetch him hither.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: We'll bring the stocks and all else, an't please your grace. Enter Bustofa and Ismenia.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: That man's my husband certain, instead of this:
Both would have deceived, and both beguiled.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Soh hoh, miller, miller, look out miller: is there never a miller amongst you here, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Yes sir, here is a miller amongst gentlemen,
A gentleman miller.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: I should not be far off then; there went but a pair of shears and a bodkin between us. Will you to work miller? Here's a maid has a sack full of news for you, shall your stones walk? will you grind miller?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This your son, Franio?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My ungracious, my disobedient,
My unnatural, my rebel son (My lord).

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Fie, your hopper runs over, miller.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This villain (Of my own flesh and blood) was accessary
To the stealing of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: O mountain,
Shalt thou call a molehill a scab upon the face
Of the earth? Though a man be a thief, shall a miller call
Him so? O egregious!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Remember sirrah, who you speak before.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I speak before a miller,
A thief in grain; for he steals corn: he that steals
A wench, is a true man to him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Can you prove that? you may help another cause that was in pleading.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I'll prove it strongly.
He that steals corn, steals the bread of the commonwealth;
He that steals a wench, steals but the flesh.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And how is the bread stealing more criminal than the flesh?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: He that steals bread, steals that which is lawful every day:
He that steals flesh, steals nothing from the fasting day:
Ergo, to steal the bread is the arranter theft.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is to some purpose.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Again, he that steals flesh, steals for his own belly full:
He that steals bread, robs the guts of others:
Ergo, the arranter thief the bread-stealer.
sp.p: Again, he that steals flesh, steals once, and gives over; yes, and often pays for it: the other steals every day, without satisfaction. To conclude, bread-stealing is the more capital crime: for what he steals he puts it in at the head: he that steals flesh (As the Dutch author says) puts it in at the foot, (The lower member.) Will you go as you are now, miller?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How has this satisfied you, don Bellides?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nothing (My lord,) my cause is serious.
I claim a daughter from that loving thief there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would I had her for you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ah ha, Julio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How said you (Antonio)? Wish you you had his daughter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With my soul I wish her; and my body
Shall perish, but I'll enjoy my souls wish.
I would have slain my friend for his deceit,
But I do find his own deceit hath paid him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Will you vex my soul forth? no other choice
But where my hate is rooted? Come hither girl,
Whose pretty maid art thou?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: The child of a poor man, sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The better for it. With my sovereign's leave,
I'll wed thee to this man, will he, nill he.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pardon me, sir, I'll be no love enforcer:
I use no power of mine unto those ends.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Wilt thou have him?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Not unless he love me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do love thee: farewell all other beauties:
I settle here: you are Ismenia.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: The same I was: better nor worse (Antonio)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I shall have your consent here, I'm sure, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: With all my heart, sir. Nay, if you accept it,
I'll do this kindness to mine enemy,
And give her as a father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She'll thank you as a daughter.
Will you not, Ismenia?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How? Ismenia?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Your daughter, sir.

sp.speaker: Believe't
sp.l: Ssipoble? Away you feeble witted things,
You thought you had caught the old ones: you wade, you wade
In shallow fords: we can swim, we: look here,
We made the match: we are all friends, good friends;
Thin, thin: why the fool knew all this, this fool.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Keep that to yourself, sir; what I knew I knew: this sack is a witness. Miller, this is not for your thumming. Here's gold lace: you may see her in her holiday clothes if you will; I was her ward-robe-man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You beguiled me well, sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Did you speak to me, sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It might seem to you (Martin), your conscience
Has quick ears.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My sight was a little dim i'th' dark, indeed,
So was my feeling cozened; yet I'm content:
I am the better understander now,
I know my wife wants nothing of a woman;
There you're my junior.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are not hurt?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not shrewdly hurt; I have good flesh to heal, you see,
Good round flesh: these cherries will be worth chopping,
Crack stones and all; I should not give much to boot
To ride in your new, and you in my old ones now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You mistake the weapon: are you not hurt?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A little scratch: but I shall claw it off well enough.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: I can no longer own what is not mine
With a free conscience: my liege, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For what? Who knows this woman?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I best (My lord),
I have been acquainted with her these forty summers,
And as many winters, were it spring again;
She's like the gout, I can get no cure for her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O, your wife, Franio?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis o my wife indeed (My lord,)
A painful stitch to my side; would it were picked out.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well sir, your silence.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Will you be older and older every day then other? the longer you live the older still? Must his majesty command your silence ere you'll hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your reprehension runs into the same fault:
Pray sir, will you be silent.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I have told him of this before now (My liege) but
Age will have his course, and his weaknesses,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Good sir, your forbearance.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: And his frailties, and his follies (As I may say) that cannot hold his tongue ere he be bidden.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why sirrah?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: But I believe your majesty will not be long troubled with him: I hope that woman has something to confess will hang 'em both.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sirrah, you'll pull your destiny upon you
If you cease not the sooner.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Nay, I have done, my liege; yet it grieves me that I should call that man father, that should be so shameless, that being commanded to hold his tongue.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To th' porter's lodge with him.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I thank your grace, I have a friend there.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Speak woman, if any interruption meet thee more,
It shall be punished sharply.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Good my liege (I dare not)
Ask you the question why that old man weeps.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who? Count Julio? I observed it not.
You hear the question sir, will you give the cause?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O my lord, it hardly will get passage,
It is a sorrow of that greatness grown,
'Less it dissolve in tears, and come by parcels.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: I'll help you sir, in the delivery,
And bring you forth a joy. You lost a daughter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Twas that recounted thought brought forth these sorrows.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: She's found again. Know you this mantle sir?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Nay leave your wonder, I'll explain it to you.
This did enwrap your child (Whom ever since
I have called mine) when nurse amaranta
In a remove from Mora to Corduba
Was seized on by a fierce and hungry bear,
She was the raven's prey, as heaven so would,
He with his booty filled, forsook the babe:
All this was in my sight: and so long I saw,
Until the cruel creature left my sight,
At which advantage I adventured me
To rescue the sweet lamb: I did it sir,
And ever since I have kept back your joy,
And made it mine: but age hath wearied me,
And bids me back restore unto the owner
What I unjustly kept these fourteen years.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O, thou hast ta'ne so many years from me,
And made me young, as was her birthday to me.
O (Good my liege) give my joys a pardon,
I must go pour a blessing on my child,
Which here would be too rude and troublesome. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Franio, you knew this before.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: O, o; item for you miller.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I did (My liege) I must confess I did,
And I confess, I ne'er would have confessed,
Had not that woman's tongue begun to me:
We poor ones love, and would have comforts, sir,
As well as great: this is no strange fault, sir,
There's many men keep other men's children
As though they were their own.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: It may stretch farther yet, I beseech you (My liege) let this woman be a little farther examined; let the words of her conscience be searched. I would know how she came by me: I am a lost child, if I be theirs: though I have been brought up in a mill, yet I had ever a mind ( methought ) to be a greater man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She will resolve you sure.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Ay, I boy: thou art mine own flesh and blood,
Born of mine own body.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: 'Tis very unlikely that such a body should bear me; there's no trust in these millers. Woman, tell the truth: my father shall forgive thee, whatsoever he was, were he knight, squire, or captain; less he should not be.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Thou art mine own child, boy.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: And was the miller my father?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Wouldst thou make thy mother a whore, knave?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Ay, if she make me a bastard. The rack must make her confess (My lord) I shall never come to know who I am else. I have a worshipful mind in me sure: methinks I do scorn poor folks.

div.stage: Enter Otrante, Florimell and Julio, etc.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Here comes the brightest glory of the day:
Love yoked with love, the best equality,
Without the level of estate or person.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You both shall be rewarded bountifully,
We'll be akin too; brother and sister
Shall be changed with us ever.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Thank you (Uncle) my sister is my cousin yet at the last cast: farewell sister foster. If I had known the civil law would have allowed it, thou hadst had another manner of husband than thou hast: but much good do thee; I'll dance at thy wedding, kiss the bride, and so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why, how now sirrah?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: 'Tis lawful now, she's none of my sister.
It was a miller and a lord
That had a scabbard and a sword,
He put it up in the country word
The miller and his daughter.
She has a face, and she can sing,
She has a grace, and she can spring,
She has a place with another thing
Tradoodle.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A knavish brother of yours (My lord).

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Would I were acquainted with your tailor (Noble brother).

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You may, there he is a mine, newly entertained.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If you have any work for me, I can fit you sir,
I fitted the lady.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: My sister (Tailor,) what fits her will hardly fit me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Who fits her may fit you sir, the tailor can do both.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: You have a true yard (Tailor.)

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ne'er a whit too long, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Then (Tailor) march with me away,
I scorn these robes, I must be gay,
My noble brother, he shall pay
Tom tailor. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your recovered friendships are sound, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: At heart, at heart (My lord) the worm shall not
Beyond many ages find a breach to enter at.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: These lovers unities I will not doubt of:
How happy have you made our progress then,
To be the witness of such fair accords?
Come, now we'll eat with you (My lord Otrante,)
'Tis a charge saved: you must not grudge your guest,
'Tis both my welcome, and your wedding-feast.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
